I calculated it, Math everyday is about 1 hour and 30 minutes, you learn about algebra in 6th grade until most likely 9th grade, and their is 180 days of school, let’s say they teach algebra in math 40 of those days, now, if we multiply the minutes spent in math per day by the days it’s taught we get roughly 3,600 minutes, or 60 hours, that means that while school teaches this shit in 60 hours, this guy taught all of it in 5.5

There you go!!

I have an idea: you build a big cylinder around the tree, and then another one without the tree. Fill up both with water, measure how much water you could fill in there, subtract one from the other = you get the volume of the tree. Now measure the moisture content of the tree (or if you cannot measure it, then assume about 50% water content if the tree is alive). Multiply this volume by the specific mass of water = you get half of the weight of the tree. Then you multiply the other half (of roughly the other 40-45% if you could measure the moisture content) of the tree volume with the specific weight of Carbon. That will be the other half weight of the tree. Add the two together, and you get the full weight of the tree. Unfortunately I can't tell right now how to include the roots - I think this method only works for the part above the ground. It's almost mindnight now and I haven't slept in 2 days, so let me know what you think :D I might come up with less insane ideas when well rested.

Well, as for the roots... maybe assume the volume of the branches, so from the full above-ground volume of the tree you would have to subtract the cylinder that's the tree trunk (d/2)^2*π*h, where "d" is the diameter of the tree, supposing that you cannot measure the "radius" directly), "h" is the height of the tree trunk. Now that you have the volume of the tree trunk, you multiply it with the specific weight of water and carbon in the ratio of the moisture content, subtract that from the full mass of the tree and you get the mass of the branches/canopy. Finally assume that the branch volume roughly equals the root volume, so you add the branch mass again to the above-ground mass of the tree, and thus you get the TOTAL MASS of the full tree without having using a scale or cutting it down.

Hello Wonderful Person! I am really bad at math. Something that has helped me is Focus and Diffuse learning. Diffuse is when you zone out and let your mind wander.  Focus is when you're mind is clear and zoned in on one thing. Try a minute of focus, zone out for a minute and think about it a bit. Find a rythym that works for you or find a type of learning that suits you. Have a great day and I hope I helped a little.
